newsitem.title: CHINA: China bans Zhang Yimou film from Cannes.
newsitem.headline: China bans Zhang Yimou film from Cannes.

text.p: China has banned the latest movie by internationally acclaimed Chinese director Zhang Yimou from competing in the Cannes film festival, industry sources said on Wednesday.
"The Ministry of Radio, Film and Television and the Film Bureau will not allow Zhang Yimou's 'Keep Cool' to be sent to Cannes," a film industry source told Reuters.
There was no official explanation for the ban on the film, which is competing for the Golden Palm award at the Cannes festival in France on May 7-18.
Zhang and film officials could not immediately be reached for comment.
"Keep Cool" is a comedy about a man who falls in love with a woman and is beaten up by her business associates.
It was not known if the film's makers would find a way to circumvent the ban and compete.
"It could be sent to Cannes through other channels even without government permission," the film industry source said.
"Zhang Yimou has not made up his mind yet whether to send the film to Cannes or not," the source said.
A second source said Zhang was unlikely to send the state-financed film to Cannes and risk the ire of China's film officials because "Keep Cool" had already been approved for local screening.
Another film industry expert said the film may have been withdrawn because it was thought unlikely to win.
It is not Zhang's first brush with Chinese officials, who frown on independent-minded film-makers.
Chinese authorities have criticised previous films by Zhang, who first triumphed in the West in 1988 with "Red Sorghum", for portraying China as backward in films for Western audiences.
Zhang's tale of four concubines, "Raise the Red Lantern", took the Silver Lion award at Venice in 1991 and was nominated for an Oscar as best foreign film.

Judges at Cannes showered honours on Zhang's "To Live" in 1994. Ge You won the best actor award for his role in the film, which tracks the sorrows and struggles of a family through the upheavals that followed the 1949 Communist revolution.
But Chinese censors did not like "To Live" and refused to allow Zhang to attend the Cannes festival after the movie was shown there without their permission.
As punishment, Zhang was told all his future films must be entirely produced and funded in China, where money is scarce and technology backward.

Chinese authorities told Zhang not to attend the New York Film Festival in 1995 where his film "Shanghai Triad" was chosen for the coveted opening slot at the event. Beijing was angered after the festival showed a documentary about the bloody 1989 crackdown on student-led pro-democracy demonstrations.
Chinese newspapers have accused Zhang and some other award-winning film directors of pandering to international judges.
China's movie mandarins have axed a number of controversial films in recent months as part of a crusade to resurrect socialist ethics, or "spiritual civilisation".
